awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identifying and modeling the advantages of regulating protein abundance in Caulobacter crescentus
awd_abstract_narration:
The cell cycle is a series of cellular events leading to DNA duplication and cell division, and ultimately to the production of two daughter cells. This project will address broadly relevant questions about cell cycle regulation. Namely, what is the function of the regulated degradation of crucial cell cycle proteins and how does this regulatory mechanism integrate with other levels of regulation to control the cell cycle?  By addressing these questions, this work has the potential to have a significant impact on our basic understanding of how the cell cycle is regulated.  This project will expose students to interdisciplinary research and allow undergraduate students in summer laboratory courses to be active participants in research.  

The timed synthesis and degradation of specific proteins is a ubiquitous mechanism of cell regulation. However, some proteins can be regulated by covalent modification or binding to an allosteric effector. If a protein's activity can be controlled without the energetic cost of degradation and resynthesis, what circumstances would favor regulation by proteolysis? To address this question, the investigators are studying CtrA, a transcriptional regulator that promotes cell division in Caulobacter, yet also blocks chromosome replication. To reconcile these opposing functions, CtrA activity is temporarily eliminated from the cell just prior to chromosome replication by both dephosphorylation and proteolysis. Caulobacter strains expressing a non-degradable version of CtrA can still initiate chromosome replication, indicating that CtrA activity can be significantly reduced by dephosphorylation alone. However, cells with non-degradable CtrA have subtle defects that may compromise their competitive fitness. During each division cycle, ~9000 CtrA molecules are degraded and resynthesized. To understand the selective advantages conferred by this apparently wasteful strategy, experimental and modeling approaches will be used to predict and test the consequences of regulating CtrA only by phosphorylation. In particular, this study will investigate whether the periodic degradation and resynthesis of a neutral passenger protein confers a competitive disadvantage in Caulobacter, as in other bacteria. Caulobacter strains expressing steady levels of a non-degradable CtrA protein will be used to identify phenotypes that differ from cells with oscillating CtrA levels. Competitive fitness assays and quantitative microscopy approaches will test explicitly the predictions of existing mathematical models, e.g., that cells with non-degradable CtrA experience a delay in chromosome replication and a longer cell division cycle. Existing deterministic and stochastic models of the Caulobacter cell cycle will be revised, taking into account recent published findings. Stochastic spatiotemporal modeling will benefit from single-cell data on times of division, chromosome replication, and protein localization.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit         

            We discovered factors that support profound cell surface remodeling in the bacterium Caulobacter crescentus. Lipid A is an essential of the outer membrane of nearly all Gram-negative bacteria. We found that Caulobacter crescentus can eliminate lipid A if the cells possess a novel negatively charged lipid, ceramide phosphoglycerate (CPG), and if the iron-responsive transcription factor Fur is deactivated. We genetically characterized the pathway for synthesizing CPG and showed that CPG can perform some functions traditionally ascribed to lipid A, such as mediating susceptibility to antimicrobial peptides used as a last line of defense against drug-resistant infections.

            These findings will enable additional research into the essential functions of lipid A, the properties of outer membrane lipids, and the structural and regulatory changes necessary to generate an outer membrane lacking lipid A. This work is important because the outer membrane is a robust barrier against antibiotics. Understanding the molecular properties of outer membrane lipids is critical for the discovery and design of new antibiotics to treat drug-resistant infections.       

            Persisters are a subset of of cells genetically identical to the rest of a bacterial population, but they have entered a temporary physiological state where they have reduced susceptibility to antibiotics. Persister cells are associated with infections that recur after one or more courses of antibiotic treatment, so it is important to understand the mechanisms that contribute to persister formation. We characterized three HipBA toxin-antitoxin systems in Caulobacter crescentus and showed that two of them increase the incidence of persister cells which resist killing by antibiotics. These two systems inhibit the activity of tRNA synthetase enzymes, which in turn inhibits protein synthesis and initiates a global stress response.

            This work showed that persister cells exist even in non-pathogenic bacteria, identified newl molecular targets of HipA toxins, demonstrated cross-talk between two HipBA systems residing in the same bacterium, and reinforced the known role of stress responses in leading to the persister state.

            Research outcomes were disseminated at 8 regional conferences, 1 national conference, and 4 international conferences. Research supported by this award resulted in 1 patent application, 1 book chapter, 2 Ph.D. dissertations, and 2 peer-reviewed journal articles.

 

Broader Impacts

            Broader Impacts were centered on a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) taught in the summers of 2018 and 2019. (Summer lab courses were not permitted at UC Berkeley in 2020 and 2021 due to the COVID19 pandemic.) Each summer, 11 students undertook similar but non-identical projects in my lab designed to generate new knowledge in microbiology. In 2018, each student knocked out a gene of unknown function in Caulobacter crescentus and characterized the properties of the resulting mutant strain. In 2019, each student investigated the effects of overproducing a Caulobacter cell cycle regulatory protein (the same protein for all students) upon the subcellular location of another protein (a different protein for each student). In the course of their projects, the students learned methods in molecular biology, microbiology, and microscopy. The key experiences of the course were obtaining results that had never before been observed, troubleshooting experiments that did not work, interpreting data, and critically examining possible sources of error.

            This award supported the training of 8 undergraduates, 3 graduate students, and 2 postdoctoral scholars in laboratory research methods. Two graduate students served as teaching assistants for the CURE, building their teaching skills. Five trainees were from groups underrepresented in STEM. All trainees are still in UC Berkeley programs or have gone on to jobs in academia or biotech or to further training in graduate or professional school.
